items.title: The Pymssql Project is Being Discontinued
items.body:
Thank you to everyone who has contributed to pymssql over the years.  Unfortunately, I believe it's time to discontinue pymssql.  It provides an incredible amount of utility to those of us that need to connect to MSSQL from Python.  But, as a project, it has failed to attract enough interest/talent/funding to maintain it.

Why discontinue it and not let someone else maintain it?  We've tried over the years.  See #516.  We have got a few people drop by to help occasionally, but nothing sustained enough to feel like transfer of the project was warranted.

I had always hoped my consulting business would be able to help maintain the library for clients that use it.  But there is too much work here for us to tackle that doesn't really benefit our client's usage and we transitioned to PyODBC earlier this year.

I'm also concerned that if I simply abandon the project a bad actor could gain control and start installing nasty stuff on what I am sure is a lot of corporate servers.

It's my hope that by discontinuing this project better solutions will be developed and/or adopted to take it's place.

# Other Related Issues

* Proposal to discontinue pymssql in favor of pyodbc #477
* Maintainers Needed - Apply Within #516
* Finding grants/funding for pymssql development #621

# Alternatives

* [pyodbc](https://github.com/mkleehammer/pyodbc): Microsoft backed
  * But see: https://github.com/level12/sqlalchemy_pyodbc_mssql
* [ctds](https://github.com/zillow/ctds): by Zillow
* [Turboodbc](https://turbodbc.readthedocs.io/): has performance enhancements including NumPy and Apache Arrow support
* [adodbapi](https://sourceforge.net/projects/adodbapi/): Windows only

# Interested in Taking Over?

Just fork pymssql and start your own project.  Gain momentum, show progress, and I'd be happy to link to your project from here.

# Next Steps

I'm going to leave this issue open for suggestions on how best to deprecate/discontinue pymssql as a project.  I'm sure there will be some who will suddenly be very interested in helping.  I won't be considering those requests at this point.  If you want to help, see above about forking.

At the end of November, 2019 I'm going to Archive this GH repository which will make it read-only.

I'll also need to figure out how to deprecate packages on PyPI so that people installing know the project is being discontinued.  

# ToDos

* [x] Notify relevant mailing lists
* [x] Update readme with notice
* [x] Publish readme notice to PyPI
* [x] Put notification into project setup/install process somehow?
* [ ] Close all open issues and PRs with notice (is there an automation tool that can help with this somewhere?)
* [ ] Archive GitHub Project
* [x] Setup RTD to no longer use pymssql.org, discontinue renewal of that domain

items.title: cursor.execute() rejecting variable passed to params argument
items.body:
I am attempting to fetch some data, passing in a tuple of parameter values to the `params` argument of `cursor.execute()`:

```Python
with pymssql.connect(server=server, port=port) as mssql:
    cursor = mssql.cursor(as_dict=True)
    cursor.execute(query.format(','.join('%d' for i in range(len(batch_keys)))), batch_keys)
    df = pd.DataFrame(cursor.fetchall())
```

This throws the following error:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ValueError                                Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-34-7e1e53cb45d9> in <module>
      2 with pymssql.connect(server='GBSHEWSQLPRD175', port='14330') as mssql:
      3     cursor = mssql.cursor(as_dict=True)
----> 4     cursor.execute(query.format(','.join('%d' for i in range(len(batch_keys[:5])))), batch_keys)
      5     df = pd.DataFrame(cursor.fetchall())

src\pymssql.pyx in pymssql.Cursor.execute()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql.MSSQLConnection.execute_query()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql.MSSQLConnection.execute_query()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql.MSSQLConnection.format_and_run_query()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql.MSSQLConnection.format_sql_command()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql._substitute_params()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql._quote_data()

src\_mssql.pyx in _mssql._quote_or_flatten()

ValueError: expected a simple type, a tuple or a list
```

The problem is that the value passed to the param argument **IS** a tuple. If I run `print(type(batch_keys), batch_keys)` the output is:

```
<class 'tuple'> (3079004, 2949733, 3444857, 3149177, 2897891)
```

And if I replace the reference to the batch_keys variable in the `.execute()` call with its actual output like so:

```Python
with pymssql.connect(server=server, port=port) as mssql:
    cursor = mssql.cursor(as_dict=True)
    cursor.execute(query.format(','.join('%d' for i in range(len(batch_keys)))), (3079004, 2949733, 3444857, 3149177, 2897891))
    df = pd.DataFrame(cursor.fetchall())
```

Then the whole thing works fine.

I have no idea what's going on there. Any ideas, please?

items.title: bson.errors.InvalidDocument: Cannot encode object: Decimal('1874.44')
items.body:
Im having this issue when im trying to insert a document in mongodb that came from pymssql.

I have the following code (that's the most performatic and resourceless way i ever seen):

```
cursor = mssql_conn.cursor(as_dict=True)
cursor.execute(query)
mongo_collection.insert_many(cursor.fetchall())
```

The thing is that pymssql assumes every monetary value returned from a query as a decimal, but mongodb needs double (any version) or decimal128 (since version 3.4+). I know that i could loop or json.dump converting this value, but i have millions and millions of rows, it will took much more time and resources, because i will have to get over every record again. 

There is a way, param or intend to make pymssql assume other types besides decimal? Can i contribute maybe creating a param for this an then converting os something?

items.title: Roadmap

labels.name: release
labels.description: Issues related to new stable releases.

items.body:
Issue #516 put out a call for maintainers(and I'm going to assume contributors as well). Since then we have had people come and go and made some updates/releases for the project. That said the issue log continues to grow, releases are inconsistent and it may not be clear what issues are worth working on if somebody wants to become a contributor.

Yesterday @rsyring was able to fast forward 2.1.x-stable into master closing #569 which felt like a blocker when addressing PRs and issues.

With that out of the way I'm hoping to document some items that I think need to be addressed to make the project easier for contributors as well as maintainers. I would love feedback on this, and I can begin to work on the admin component of opening related issues, review, closing old request, etc. 

At this time I'm going to group things into releases since I think putting a timeline on them is a little premature today. I will note that the rest of 2.x is focused more on stabilizing the developer experience and project status versus features while beginning to look at feature expansion in a future 3.x release.

**`2.1.5`**
- Document build & release process #204 
- Release from master with the PRs that have been accepted since the 2.1.4 release
- Announce 2.1.x going into bug fix mode
- Review and complete [milestone](https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/milestone/6) issues from 2.1.2 or move to 2.2.0 if appropriate.


**`2.2.0`**
- Implement items from the 2.2.x Changelog see #569 
```
- Stop using 7.1 as default value for the TDS protocol version used in connections.

  This is a backward incompatible change and affects connections using both
  `pymssql` and `_mssql`.

  Now you need to specify a TDS protocol version explicitly by using any of
  the supported mechanisms (in descending order of precedence):

  * Using the ``tds_version`` paramenter of ``pymssql.connect()`` and
    ``_mssql.connect()``
  * A ``TDSVER`` enviromnent variable (see FreeTDS documentation)
  * A ``freetds.conf`` file (see FreeTDS documentation)

- Drop support for versions of FreeTDS older than 0.91.
- Accept 7.3 as TDS protocol version when establishing a connection.
```
- Setup CI to be on a testing matrix using FreeTDS 1.0 and 1.1
- Setup GitHub Issue templates for features and bug reports
- Review and close open issues older than 90 days that do not have enough information to replicate/fix the issue. Close any where FreeTDS is older than 0.91.
- Review and close open PRs that are older than 90 days and cannot be merged/do not have tests.
- Review [milestones](https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/milestones), update url if it makes sense and close out existing milestones while creating new ones for each release.
- Setup monthly builds checking for deprecation etc. similar to what happens with [aioodbc](https://github.com/aio-libs/aioodbc/pull/187)
- Review if appveyor builds can be moved to a set of docker images
- Review CircleCI build. I did this early on in my docker experience, I'm sure it can be cleaned up, and we may need multiple images or multiple images may make it easier to do the matrix of testing with different FreeTDS versions, sql server etc.
- Run SQLAlchemy test suite with pymssql as part of the build process
- Create 2.2.x release with merged PRs, test etc
- Setup Windows and Linux docker images for contributor development


`3.0.0`
- Switch to only using FreeTDS with OpenSSL included
- Switch to only supporting FreeTDS 1.x
- Update to the latest Cython version, update Cython build steps, fix Cython deprecations
- Add OSX to CI
- Switch to new manylinux/pereniallinux [PEP 513](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0513/)
- Review Cython/FreeTDS bridge and feature coverage
- Review documentation updates, does 1.x still need mention, ssl coverage, build/developer experience etc.


Thoughts? Feedback? What am I missing? I'll give until next Monday for some feedback then I'll work on some of the items for 2.1.5 next week. I don't have as much extra time for contributing code, but I can work on reviewing PRs, announcements and documentation as well as helping those interested on board.

items.title: pymssql doesn't recognize and cleanup dead connections after failover with freetds 1.1
items.body:
Hello team. We're sailing into uncharted territory here at SurveyMonkey so some surprises are expected.

When SQL Server triggers a failover and our apps are running the following stack

>
SQLAlchemy: 1.1.9
pymssql: 2.1.4
TDS protocol: 7.4
FreeTDS: 1.1
OS: Ubuntu Bionic (18.04)

connections are not being recognized as dead and marked for cleanup as expected. This results in SQL Alchemy attempting to re-use the connections over and over, failing with errors at the freeTDS and pymssql boundary until the connections are eventually recycled when their TTL is reached. This happens for connections regardless of whether they are using availability group (i.e. multi-subnet) or non-availability group listeners.

After some digging, there seems to be a divide between the severity of the error being sent to pymssql's error handler from freeTDS, which relays message 20047 `DBPROCESS is dead or not enabled` as a severity level 1. Since the severity level is under the min_severity_level of 6, pymssql short-circuit returns an INT_CANCEL without checking if the connection is dead (https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/blob/master/src/_mssql.pyx#L230), resulting in the aforementioned connection reuse behavior in SQL Alchemy.

I don't know enough about the severity levels and their intent to whether freetds should be specifying a higher severity level or in which library this issue should be fixed. However, we have been testing a pymssql build with the severity check moved down to after line 261 which seems to work, but I'm not sure of the implications of that besides what _seems_ to be a somewhat negligible amount of additional work due to the last msg var assignments and DBDEAD calls, the latter which seems to be only a few boolean checks on the underlying connection.

What are your thoughts? Does the fix belong in pymssql or freetds, and if the former, would something along the lines of the patch outlined above be acceptable? If so, I'll create a PR to get things started.

Thanks,
Jon

items.title: Finding grants/funding for pymssql development
items.body:
My company, Level 12, has decided to undertake an initiative to find grants or other sources of funding for pymssql development.  We have internal resources that can contribute to the funding, but they are currently inadequate to make a significant dent in the tech debt that is present in pymssql.

Our hope is that we can find someone at Microsoft who would be willing to help sponsor development of this project.  Microsoft officially supports pyodbc, but based on #477, pymssql still has a lot of value when connecting unix systems to Microsoft SQL server.

If anyone has connections at Microsoft that we might be able to use and/or any other large corporations that use pymssql that might consider helping to fund development, please leave comments here or contact me directly (email in GitHub profile).

No one on my team has ever tried to raise support for an OSS project before.  So if you have any suggestions, please feel free to leave them here as well.

items.title: About the autocommit
items.body:
> Just note
```python
with pymssql.connect(server, user, password, 'tempDB') as conn:
    with conn.cursor(as_dict=True) as cursor:
        cursor.callproc(...)
```
If this code raise:
```
_mssql.MSSQLDatabaseException: (266, b'Transaction count after EXECUTE indicates a mismatching number of BEGIN and COMMIT statements. Previous count = 1, current count = 0.DB-Lib error message 20018, severity 16:\nGeneral SQL Server error: Check messages from the SQL Server\n')
```
you can set `autocommit=True`:
```python
with pymssql.connect(server, user, password, 'tempDB', autocommit=True) as conn:
    with conn.cursor(as_dict=True) as cursor:
        cursor.callproc(...)
```

Enjoy coding~

labels.name: build

items.body:
As we work towards the release of 2.1.4 I can see that it is 56 commits ahead of `master` today. Looking at the git branching history I also see activity on master for 2.2.x. 

Can we say that 2.1.4 is the last 2.1.x release? Would there be any reason for 2.1.x to continue with active work moving to 2.2.x?

I'm assuming we will want all updates from 2.1.4 in 2.2.x, but not knowing the full history I wanted to ask if that is a safe assumption when looking into merging the changes and looking at any extra strategies that may be required to reconcile the branches.

items.title: Removing non-active maintainers
items.body:
@damoxc, @jpgimenez, @msabramo, @ramiro, @yuvalbar:

Greetings gents!  As part of our effort to start putting more time into pymssql, we are taking a look at the project as a whole and making sure project access on GitHub and PyPI is limited to users that need it.

Please let me know if you believe you will have time to contribute to pymssql project in the next 6 months or so.  If not, then I'd like to remove your access from the project.

Not trying to be heavy handed at all, which is why I'm creating this issue and asking for feedback.  I'm just trying to operate on the [Principle of Least Privilege](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_privilege).

If I don't hear back from any of you in the next couple weeks, I'll assume that is confirmation that your access can be removed.

If you are removed and any of you have contributions you want to make in the future, we'll be happy to add you back to the project as needed.

Thanks.

#539, #536 are related.

items.title: Older Python (3.4): "bytes object has no attribute 'encode'" when working with connect statements.
items.body:
Yes, I know, Python 3.4 is *old* and *decrepit* but there's an older system here that we are stuck with that uses Python 3.4.

When attempting to use `pymssql`, we get traceback indicating that there is an attribute error somewhere, such that we get this error traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./threader.py", line 642, in <module>
    main()
  File "./threader.py", line 240, in main
    if not Database.server_available():
  File "/home/threader/Threader3/bin/ThreaderLib/remote/_Database.py", line 38, in server_available
    db_password=db_password)
  File "/home/threader/Threader3/bin/ThreaderLib/remote/_Database.py", line 63, in open_connection
    return pymssql.connect(host=db_host, user=db_user, password=db_password)
  File "pymssql.pyx", line 635, in pymssql.connect (pymssql.c:10734)
  File "_mssql.pyx", line 1902, in _mssql.connect (_mssql.c:21821)
  File "_mssql.pyx", line 569, in _mssql.MSSQLConnection.__init__ (_mssql.c:6135)
AttributeError: 'bytes' object has no attribute 'encode'
```

Somewhere along the line, you're attempting to convert a string to bytes, is my guess, but that's not going to work for a `bytes` object.  Any chance this is an issue in `pymssql` that's fixable for older-software compatibility purposes?  Or should I be hunting some other MSSQL interface library?

@damoxc @ramiro: Obviously it would help pymssql if we had maintainers who had more time for the project.  I propose leaving this issue open as a signal to others that we have need and are willing to give others commit privileges.  I also believe we could contact a few of the people who submitted PRs recently to see if they are interested in helping more.  Any objections?

To others: if you have interest and time to help pymssql progress, please leave a message here.

Anyone having issues with azure and their ssl protocol timing out after about 25 - 30 minutes?

I'm trying to find a mechanism (at this time im thinking something as simple as a port ping from within the driver) to prevent the connection from dropping.

Any ideas on how something like this would be implemented in pymssql?

items.title: Repository size
items.body:
Because
* of my need to install pymssql from source due to ([issue 432](https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/issues/432#issuecomment-238257092))
* the `pip install` was taking so long on my machine
* `pip install` does not support the `depth` parameter that `git clone` has ([ref](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/20101834/pip-install-from-git-repo-branch#comment73371735_24811490))


I was looking at the pymssql repository size. Downloading it shows that it's a mere ~700 KB, but cloning it shows that it's around 14MB.

The bash script [here](http://stevelorek.com/how-to-shrink-a-git-repository.html) that lists large files in a repository shows the following
```
size  pack  SHA                                       location
3629  3592  53466ca5870402f2e54c5d500629808e0bfe3ea0  win32/freetds.zip
2374  827   87b3ac4d88046e3c1795f73c7c3b155e87db27c5  freetds/vs2008_32/lib/db-lib.lib
2118  638   93fda1d7f41f30dfe2fb91fffb59a832773ee6fa  freetds/nix_64/lib/libsybdb.a
1501  544   a2f009f11c35ff4bc7c7de223a8ba517c177a6f6  freetds/vs2008_32/lib/tds.lib
1492  612   ee526b3437773eb6f56b39540cdeee8bb0c96af8  freetds/nix_32/lib/libsybdb.a
1455  1435  a76e0390a2616331c751b4336bc40c5515b7e8c8  win32/freetds.zip
982   292   566720b7916fdee35005904984ef6a763502c452  freetds/nix_64/lib/libsybdb.a
903   235   39444f4ef8e41d6681f0a53556a9c43035d6ced4  freetds/nix_64/lib/libsybdb.a
701   230   eabab9a9891588c5995d3eecfa39668cca4385bc  freetds/nix_32/lib/libsybdb.a
701   258   d6874fc1cbb08f4388cecce433ec4f8d285800d5  freetds/nix_32/lib/libsybdb.a
```
It seems that your commit history contains copies of `win32/freetds.zip` of about 5 MB.
Removing those 2 files from the history could cut the `pip install` size by a third.

To help more, I tried to get the commit date of the first SHA with `git log --oneline 53466ca5870402f2e54c5d500629808e0bfe3ea0`, but that doesn't show anything. If I replace `log` with `show`, then I get a bunch of binary output, and no dates at all.
What are your thoughts on this? Do you think this is worth it?

items.title: Support OpenSSL 1.1.0+ lib names in Windows
items.body:
*THIS ISSUE HAS THE SAME ROOT AS https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/984*

Since the release of OpenSSL 1.1.0, library names - **ssleay32.lib** and **libeay32.lib** - have been changed to **libssl.lib** and **libcrypto.lib**. That's why building pymssql with SSL support won't succeed even by following [guide](https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/blob/master/docs/freetds.rst#windows) on Windows.

https://www.npcglib.org/~stathis/downloads/openssl-1.1.0b-vs2015.7z
https://www.npcglib.org/~stathis/downloads/openssl-1.0.2j-vs2015.7z

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/721858/26756127/e2f51000-48d6-11e7-958e-6573e60851d7.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/721858/26756124/d75c0f3c-48d6-11e7-9430-7efc11d8c204.png)

**Where the names are written**

https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/blob/v2.1.3/setup.py#L297
https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/blob/v2.1.3/setup.py#L307

**My idea how to fix it**

Make `setup.py` look at one more environmental variable like `PYMSSQL_BUILD_WITH_OPENSSL` with adding proper documentation about it.

1. If the environmental variable is available, then set `LINK_OPENSSL` to `True` at the very beginning.
2. If `LINK_OPENSSL` is true, then try to parse version info of OpenSSL from the environmental variable.
3. If the environmental variable looks like 1.1.0+, then use `libsslMD.lib` and `libcryptoMD.lib`.
4. If the environmental variable looks like 1.0.x or below, then keep `'libeay{}MD'.format(BITNESS)` and `'ssleay{}MD'.format(BITNESS)`
5. If the environmental variable doesn't look like version info (e.g. just YES), then assume 1.1.0+ with annotating the assumption.

**Concerns about my idea**

- What format looks like valid version info, e.g. `(\d+\.\d+\.\d+)[a-z]*`, `^(\d\.\d\.\d)[a-z]$`, etc.
- How to avoid to break build on non-Windows environments.
- The fix would do too much; There'd be smarter idea to fix the issue.

items.title: Proposal to discontinue pymssql in favor of pyodbc
items.body:
From https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/pymssql/CLXHtLKBWig:

> Back when I started working with pymssql, pyodbc wasn't in very good shape.  However, Microsoft has just announced official support for pyodbc:
> 
> https://blogs.technet.microsoft.com/dataplatforminsider/2016/12/09/sql-server-python-whats-new/
> 
> * There are official pyodbc drivers from Microsoft for Linux: https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/hh568451(v=sql.110).aspx
> * FreeTDS also provides an ODBC driver.
> 
> With that announcement, it seems we might be fighting an up-hill battle to keep pymssql maintained.  Most users will gravitate towards pyodbc as the "official" solution for mssql.  We already struggle to attract enough developer talent to keep pymssql updated as recent issue requests for a new release show.

I only got once response on the ML and it agreed that pymssql should go.  

I want to start broadcasting this proposal to a larger audience, I'm thinking:

- Python Announce ML
- DB-Sig
- SQLAlchemy ML

------------

If anyone has solid technical reasons for why pymssql should be continued, please comment here.

items.title: Transactions behaviour
items.body:
We debugged situation with transactions issues we faced and find out that pymssql opens transaction on connection start with "BEGIN TRAN" and after conn.commit() it commits already opened transaction and then open new one again.

It seems its a "feature" when autocommit settings is off. And this is VERY BAD practice to keep transaction open because of locks and concurrency between database connections. Of course your can write NOLOCK option for every SELECT in every program that uses this database but this is a bad practice too.

Its nice to see a way to start start transaction by programmers own choice ex. conn.begin() without any auto transaction features. This auto feature must be smart - it must detect a query that changes data and only then starts transaction just before executing query, there is already way in SQL Server to do that, it is called [IMPLICIT TRANSACTIONS](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/ms187807.aspx) and you can use it - you only need to change query in commit to IF @@TRANCOUNT > 0 COMMIT TRAN and its gonna work really well

At least this moment must be shown in doc with **bold** because this cause a lot of problems

``` python
conn = pymssql.connect(server='server', user='sa', password='123456', database='tempdb')
cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("SELECT 'hello'")
conn.commit()
```

Profiler trace:

``` sql
use [tempdb]
go
BEGIN TRAN
go
SELECT 'hello'
go
COMMIT TRAN
go
BEGIN TRAN
go
```

I'm still kinda some shocked, please tell me 'm dreamin :)

items.title: Resulting in python to stop working, the process automatically exit
items.body:
environment:
pymssql-2.1.3, python-2.7

Use the following pseudo-code
while True:
   if conn == None:
      connect database method
   try:
      query (sql)
    except Exception, e:
      conn.close ()
      conn == None

   time.sleep (2)

Connect to the database sucessful
Unplug the network cable,
Wait a few seconds, then plug the Internet cable
Connect again, this will be reported error (20004, '\ x06 \ x08DB-Lib error message 20004, severity 9: \ nRead from the server failed \ nNet-Lib error during Unknown error (10054) \ n')
And will lead to python.exe process exit
what reason?
Thank you

items.title: Queries returning None result, work fine from other client applications
items.body:
I'm running a simple select query against a SQL Server 2014 DB (version 12.1.4100.1):

This is the code I'm running:

```
>>> import pymssql
>>> conn = pymssql.connect('localhost', '***', '***', 'ItemsCmsLgTest', as_dict=True)
>>> c = conn.cursor()
>>> res = c.execute("SELECT * FROM ucpItemDescriptors WHERE ItemId = '86292440-8000-48AF-92E6-B3EE15EFF6D2'")
>>> res.fetchone()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'fetchone'
```

The same query works fine when running from another client application, and oddly, queries to some tables work fine.

It also seems from the FreeTDS logs (attached) that it does get results back, but for some reason I still get `None` back. The query execution in the FreeTDS logs are in the last 100-150 rows or so.

There are no error messages anywhere as far as I can tell.

I have only seen this happen where the column I'm selecting on (ItemId in this case) is of type UNIQUEIDENTIFIER, but that might be a red herring.

**pymssql version:** 2.1.3
**FreeTDS version:** 0.91-6.1build1

[freetds.txt](https://github.com/pymssql/pymssql/files/369239/freetds.txt)
